department_name: Orange County Health Care Agency - Environmental Health Division

grading_system.description: Orange County uses a pass/fail placard system instead of letter grades. Facilities receive Pass, Reinspection Due-Pass, or Closed placards.

inspection_details.frequency: Risk-based routine inspections based on facility type and risk category identification
inspection_details.reinspection_trigger: Major violations observed and corrected require follow-up inspection on date posted on seal
inspection_details.public_disclosure: Most recent inspection report required to be available at facility for public view upon request; online inspection database available at inspections.myhealthdepartment.com

fire_safety_authority.department_name: Orange County Fire Authority (OCFA) and local fire departments
fire_safety_authority.ansul_system_requirements: Commercial kitchen fire suppression systems required per NFPA standards and local fire codes
fire_safety_authority.inspection_frequency: Semi-annual inspection and testing of restaurant hood suppression systems typically required

regulatory_framework.food_code_basis: California Retail Food Code (CalCode) - part of California Health and Safety Code, based on FDA Food Code
regulatory_framework.state_vs_local_authority: County Environmental Health Division conducts inspections under California Retail Food Code authority
regulatory_framework.local_ordinances: Orange County ordinances supplement state California Retail Food Code requirements

confidence_notes: Orange County's pass/fail system is well-documented across multiple official sources. The county explicitly chose this system over letter grades despite pressure from grand jury reports.
verification_notes: Orange County is definitively confirmed to use pass/fail placards rather than letter grades. The county has approximately 15,000 food facilities under California Retail Food Code enforcement.
